posts.name:
steven kamensky
steven kamensky
posts.content:
Happy Wednesday! 
As we embrace the middle of the week, let's remember the importance of spending our energy in the present moment. Every day is a precious gift, and living in the "now" is the key to true happiness and fulfillment. 
Focus on what you can do today to make the most of your time and create beautiful memories. Let go of past regrets and future anxieties, and pour your energy into the present. It's the little moments that make life extraordinary. 
Wishing you an awesome day ahead! Let's live each day to the fullest and cherish every moment. 
I hope this brings a smile to your face and inspires those around you!

posts.name:
ü¶æJepson Taylor
ü¶æJepson Taylor
posts.content:
I've been thinking more about brain efficiency. With my last startup I was doing polyphasic sleeping where I would go to bed at 11pm and wake up at 2:30am every day to work. You can do this if you are good at taking micro naps during the day. During that time I had feedback from an investor and my co-founder that I might need more sleep because I was showing signs of cognitive decay.

Recently I was catching up with a CEO who mentioned their sleeping the last few months was on point, many nights getting the full 8hrs of sleep.

So here is my main question, between fighting for minimal sleep, and ideal sleep (aka sleep until your body wakes up) what is the ideal? I think the answer to that question is beyond human, I think it ultimately will come down to AI's assessment of our work.

For example, if you are programming, then all of the code you check in through git should be automatically analyzed and scored by an agent. Scored for it's unit of work (complexity, value, etc.. however you define that) and then your units of work should be tracked/day.

If you are producing more on the world's most terrible sleep schedule... there you go... if you are producing more on sleep closer to your ideal target (8hrs) there you go. I'm curious if anyone has done this level of tracking, also what tricks/tips to people use/do to maximize their cognitive throughput (e.g. lions mane, bacopa monnieri, omega-3, ginko biloba, vitamin B, cardio, ice baths, etc..).

Curious what tips people have out there and what they do sleep-wise to maximize throughput at work.

comments.commentText: Great insights! Balancing sleep and productivity is crucial. Id love to hear others‚Äô experiences with tracking their cognitive performance relative to sleep.

This also reminds me of my first job out of school... they had a 'butts in seats' mentality... cared about how much you sat at your desk. We should all be measured by output, and come up with systems to track/measure that.

posts.name:
Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
posts.content:
Not a lunatic. That‚Äôs what the Reddit subgroup has to say about me, and they never say anything nice. 

Whoever thought it would be a good thing to have someone submit your post in LinkedIn Lunatics Reddit subgroup.

Someone sent me a link as I don‚Äôt use the platform and I did not even know this subgroup existed, so I checked it out.

LinkedIn Lunatics is a Reddit subgroup that makes fun of cringy LinkedIn posts. The thought that only a lunatic could have written the post.

Well, I guess I broke the group because I‚Äôve had 3 different posts of mine reposted with praise, which is not really a Reddit thing I hear. I've gotten more than a handful of clients from Reddit.

BTW, I really don‚Äôt swear that much. I just get a little passionate once in a while. I think it's an East Coast thing.

comments.commentText: I‚Äôm so scared to go on Reddit these days.
Nikki Lang have you used it before? I've only gone when someone sends me a link. Who's got time for all of it.

Nikki Lang, same! I'm even more scared to comment on anything. They are ruthless.  

Dan, I've seen some of the posts in the LinkedIn Lunatics sub, and they are pretty crazy. I don't think any of yours should be on there though!

posts.name:

Arielle Berlinsky
posts.content:
Ô∏èBig news dropped for the world of Starbucks coffee loversÔ∏è


Starbucks customers now have to pay to sit inside.

Yes, you read that right. This ties into the company‚Äôs changes in its code of conduct.

‚ÄúWe want everyone to feel welcome and comfortable in our stores. By setting clear expectations for behavior and use of our spaces, we can create a better environment for everyone,‚Äù Jaci Anderson told the AP.

Customers have to order something in order to dine in, hang out, or use their bathroom.

Sara Trilling, the Starbucks North America President explained, ‚ÄúThere is a need to reset expectations for how our spaces should be used, and who uses them.‚Äù

This all stems from the greater changes being made under CEO Brian Niccol, who wants to make Starbucks come back to its old community coffee shop vibe.

What do you think about these implemented changes?

posts.name:
Parantap Chowdhury
Parantap Chowdhury
posts.content:
You‚Äôre stuck in your sales associate role.

The biggest problems?

Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned after interviewing or training 100+ sales leaders, managers and associates in the last 6 months:

No clear promotion path.
Constantly hitting targets but not moving up.
Watching others get ahead while you stay in place.

Here‚Äôs why:

- You‚Äôre seen as a prospector, not a closer
- Your skills don‚Äôt show direct revenue impact
- You haven‚Äôt demonstrated full-cycle sales ability

Want to shift gears and make that jump?

1. Close small deals to prove you're a closer
2. Build visibility and relationships with leadership
3. Show your impact on revenue, even in small wins
4. Shadow seniors, take on more closing responsibilities


Result ‚Üì

No more being stuck.

Bigger deals.
Higher commissions.
A clear path to manager and beyond.

P.S. I break down more growth strategies with TSAP.

Want in? Click on 'visit my website' or DM.
